newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Microsoft Expedia sales rise.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Microsoft Expedia sales rise.

text.p: Sales of airline tickets and other travel-related items over the Internet executed using Microsoft Corp's Expedia technology have risen past $2 million per week, a company executive said Wednesday.

Microsoft group vice president Pete Higgins said in an interview that Microsoft gets a percentage of each sale although he declined to specify, saying the amount varies depending on whether the sale is executed over the company's own Expedia Web site or on a separately branded site that uses Microsoft software.
Northwest Airlines Corp and Continental Airlines operate Web sites that use the Expedia technology, Higgins said.
He said sales are sure to rise with American Express Co's AXI, a new Internet travel venture using Microsoft technology that will start with corporate travel services and expand to consumers.
The American Express product is in a test phase, and Higgins said 130 companies have volunteered to participate.
"We really can't meet the demand," he said.

Higgins said Expedia was just an example of Microsoft Internet technology that could be used to capture a portion of the increasing sales of products and services conducted over the vast computer network.
Other promising interactive ventures include Carpoint, the company's car shopping service, and Investor, which allows users to track stocks and financial news, he said.
